A very long, thin, nonconducting cylinder of length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is centered on the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> -axis, as shown above. (a)

i. On the figure shown below, draw an arrow to indicate the direction of the electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> due to the long cylinder. The arrow should start on and point away from the dot.

ii. Describe the shape and location of a Gaussian surface that can be used to determine the electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> due to the long cylinder.

iii. Use your Gaussian surface to derive an expression for the magnitude of the electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="lambda" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="c" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> , and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) A proton is released from rest at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the axes below, sketch the velocity <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of position <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of position <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the proton.

The original cylinder is now replaced with a much shorter thin, nonconducting cylinder with the same uniform linear charge density <math alttext="positive lambda" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>λ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the figure below. The length of the cylinder to the right of the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> -axis is <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the length of the cylinder to the left of the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> -axis is <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="a is less than b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo><</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) On the figure shown below, draw an arrow to indicate the direction of the electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> due to the shorter cylinder. The arrow should start on and point away from the dot.

(d)

i. Is there a single Gaussian surface that can be used with Gauss’s law to derive an expression for the electric field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

Yes No

ii. If your answer to part (d)(i) is yes, explain how you can use Gauss’s law to derive an expression for the field at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If your answer to part (d)(i) is no, explain why Gauss’s law cannot be applied to derive an expression for the electric field in this case.
